body:
> excludes only by whole directory

so are we keeping the exclusion of tests/dat?

in case it's not clear: my preference is to continue excluding tests/dat from scans and to not put headers in those assets. i'd like to understand why it should be the other way around if that's the plan (I see it of little value). hence my questions.

@rabbah I would like to have as few directory exclusions as possible (hopefully only "bin") after we add licenses to other files in same subdir.  unless we are testing EOL spaces or TABs; I assumed these were functional tests for the runtimes, not syntax tests which scancode is used for?

>continue excluding tests/dat

I agree let's continue to exclude this `tests/dat`

I consider this directory a test "fixture" meaning input params for test.

I don't consider them source code that test the product that requires conventions, we could have input files that don't follow convention on purpose to see if openwhisk handles them correctly, can I have a python script that has a line of 400 characters and does openwhisk handle this? well I could create a file in `tests/dat`.
@dubeejw when you add a change like this to the API - please add a test with it (or mark it wip with a comment).
@ddragosd do these changes affect your deployment tools with docker compose?

Yes it does in the current `master` branch : https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-devtools/blob/0326d39c7b76207815a5fb551846423d124d5d89/docker-compose/Makefile#L122 

But we have a PR to use the `ansible` script to setup a DB in this PR: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-devtools/pull/10

Actually the more important PR is #1928 . If we could review this we're solving more use-cases.
Bonus points if one of those swift files can be `Pacakge.swift` and so we can pull in dependencies?!

We can exclude tests/dat, but it seems odd to have to strip out license headers if the tests have IP (very little for sure); however, if you want me to I can (just delete headers for that directory) as I really want to get this merged so I we can actually start scanning Python... 

I still plan to keep the literal (descriptive) headers if that is ok and just remove the license portion?

@akrabat the cold start times may be killer with full Swift Package Manager support.  However, its worth investigating!

The pre-compilation of a Swift Package seems like a better approach.

I'm not sure of the root cause, but using `openwhisk/swift3action` seems to create a binary which isn't properly linked to the Whisk object -- the action crashes silently when you use it.

I created a new container from the openwhisk/core/swift3action myself and modified the compile.sh script to use it.  I was able to get the code above to work.

Steps I did:

1. Copy action proxy code:
`$ cp  $openwhiskhome/core/actionproxy/actionproxy.py $openwhiskhome/core/swift3Action`

2. build image
`$ cd $openwhisk/core/swift3Action`
`$ docker build -t swifty .`

3. modify compile script to use swifty image

Change line 3:
`docker run -it -v "$(pwd):/owexec" openwhisk/swift3action bash -e -c " ` 
to:
`docker run -it -v "$(pwd):/owexec" swifty bash -e -c "`

4. compile `compile.sh hello`
test/dat/*.py have license headers removed in PR now, left any PEP8 changes (incl. docstring adds).
Neato! We should probably add a test for this though.
Travis failure unrelated. Confirmed works as expected.

> Neato! We should probably add a test for this though.

Will do.

The file extension might not be the same as language name so it would be helpful if you could add a file_suffix like `.py` for python, `.rb` for ruby, `.pl` for perl, etc.  By parsing this data structure, clients could dynamically support new languages or reject requests for unsupported file extensions.

that's correct for a private package.
for a public package (`wsk package update xyz --public`), it is available to all authenticated users (read and invoke only).

you may want to ask these questions on http://slack.openwhisk.org/.

@cclauss 

> - [x] So does your solution above work in both Python 2 and Python 3?

Yes.

> - [ ] Does it pass the two tests mentioned above?

Only one of the tests actually exists anymore.  I do not see any failures in Jenkins.

> - [x] Is this PR ready for review?

Maybe? (see below)

> - [x] Are there other places where we could see similar bytes vs. strings issues?

If I had to give an answer, then I'd say we're sure to hit one or two issues down the line ;-).  Since `actionproxy.py` is going to straddle the Python2/3 world, we should probably follow [recommended practices](https://docs.python.org/3/howto/pyporting.html#text-versus-binary-data), including

> 1. Decide which of your APIs take text and which take binary data
> 2. Make sure that your code that works with text also works with unicode and code for binary data works with bytes in Python 2 (see the table above for what methods you cannot use for each type)
> 3. Mark all binary literals with a 'b' prefix, textual literals with a 'u' prefix
> 4. Decode binary data to text as soon as possible, encode text as binary data as late as possible
> 5. Open files using `io.open()` and make sure to specify the b mode when appropriate

Right now, this PR handles (4).  I can include additional commits to this PR to address (3) and (5) rather easily.

remind me again why can't python scripts be located in `/tests/dat/` and have a license header?

Can't we just exclude `/tests/dat/` from nay scanning, and we don't care if the scripts have a header or not, if they have one OK if they don't OK also.

> remind me again why can't python scripts be located in /tests/dat/ and have a license header?

there's no such restriction - my point is about consistency and that these tests assets dont need it in general.

i think we've belabored the point - since @mrutkows has removed them already i suggest to accept the pr in its current state.

@starpit, it'd be very helpful if you posted the exact options you are using to send the request. Below are some options I experimented with and the results.

Works as expected.
```
var options = {
  method: 'POST',
  url: "https://192.168.99.100/api/v1/experimental/web/.../default/headers.json",
  body: JSON.stringify({"key": "value"}),
  headers: {
    Content-Type': 'application/json'
  }
};

POST /api/v1/experimental/web/.../default/headers.json HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/json
host: 192.168.99.100
accept: application/json
content-length: 15
Connection: close
```

Works as expected.
```
var options2 = {
  method: 'POST',
  json: true,
  url: "https://192.168.99.100/api/v1/experimental/web/.../default/headers.json",
  body: {"key": "value"},
};

POST /api/v1/experimental/web/.../default/headers.json HTTP/1.1
host: 192.168.99.100
accept: application/json
content-type: application/json
content-length: 21
Connection: close
```

Does not work as a content-type is not sent. Maybe we should default to application/json if content-type isn't sent?
```
var options3 = {
  method: 'POST',
  url: "https://192.168.99.100/api/v1/experimental/web/.../default/headers.json",
  body: JSON.stringify({"key": "value"}),
};

POST /api/v1/experimental/web/.../default/headers.json HTTP/1.1
host: 192.168.99.100
content-length: 15
Connection: close
```

Does not work as expected because the body is a string not JSON
```
var options4 = {
  method: 'POST',
   json: true,
  url: "https://192.168.99.100/api/v1/experimental/web/.../default/headers.json",
  body: '{"key": "value"}'
};

POST /api/v1/experimental/web/.../default/headers.json HTTP/1.1
host: 192.168.99.100
accept: application/json
content-type: application/json
content-length: 22
Connection: close
```
Added PATCH verb. I get a compilation error when adding TRACE. Might need another import?
CORS test may not be stable.

@csantanapr they can both have a license header and be excluded.  The discussion seemed to lean towards why have them at all it seemed to me.  Can we squash/merge if this is going to a longer discussion that has little effect on running code?
going to close as duplicate of https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1959.

since i closed the pr to store this setting, i'm also closing the issue as wont fix.
there's a documented workaround for "local" deployments in https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1989 for Vagrant and will add additional documentation as part of #1908.
This is already done with the newest health protocol, isn't it?
@jeremiaswerner @domdom82 @markusthoemmes some of the issues/prs in flight should perhaps be linked to this epic, no?

The health protocol informs the controller of invoker health - which might as well be kafka health if there are no messages received. I intended in this issue to also tie that to the active ack short circuiting and fall over to the datastore for activations. You're pointing out that the period for which this would be an issue with the new health protocol is much shorter than the previous 30 seconds. I agree.
This can be solved via annotations. Still valid/needed @starpit ?
Is this solved by dropping the schemas @dubeejw ?
Not relevant/covered by more specific issues.
closing as duplicate of 270 - will make that into an epic.
I think this is done, looking at: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/feeds.md
this PR is still open: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1707 adds userns to docker-machine
